intro: Ophiorrhiza borii, commonly known as the Malabar sandalwood, is a flowering plant belonging to the family Rhizophoraceae. It is characterized by its unique morphological features, including a short, thick stem and opposite, ovate leaves with a leathery texture. The plant produces small, white flowers that are clustered in inflorescences, followed by small, spherical fruits. It is typically found in coastal and sandy soils, often in mangrove or brackish water environments. Ophiorrhiza borii plays a role in stabilizing coastal ecosystems and is adapted to saline conditions.
